body: I often get this kind of failure on completely unrelated tests. The cure for me is to restart my machine :-( But sometimes this also shows actual problem, like when I had a runaway evaluator which kept running after test ended.
@markusweimer addresses some comments and responded in the PR to questions
@markusweimer Do you have more comments on this one?

I've updated PR. 
Test failed for poisoning on `TaskStop` event, because completing task took some time after this event for AppVeyor runs, and poison acted before task was really stopped, thus producing failed task. Task closing time is not something we can control, so I added a little delay to poison. Now tests pass [on my branch](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/tcNickolas/reef/build/80-REEF-1304) (our AppVeyor is a bit behind with the queue)
I'll do a pass.
I have tested Driver Restart on an HDInsight cluster.

Done with a pass. This and the other currently open pull request make me question the design of the multi-runtime, as even the most trivial changes require code changes all over the place. I left some thoughts on how to maybe clean this up on [REEF-936](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-936)

@dkm2110 I have addressed your review comments. 
My test shows batch id can be reused within one driver. But I still changed it to append a sequence number, that would be also good for log info.

It's a pretty simple, straightforward implementation. I wasn't sure if supplementing tests were needed.
Please feel free to correct me if I've done something not right!
@dkm2110 Do you have any comments, or can this be merged?

`TaskRuntime.cs` still uses `Logger.CustomLevel` directly. @afchung Is there any specific reason for this code to do the logic of comparing log levels instead of calling `IsLoggable`, or can this be replaced?

Other than this, looks good to me

Given that we plan to do more work in the APIs, I changed my code review focus to making sure everything exposed is marked `@Unstable`. I have done a pass to that effect.

Just like for #966, I have changed focus to making sure that everything is unstable to allow for the API changes in 0.16. Please change those instances and make sure things pass tests on a YARN cluster. After that, I am +1 to merge.
Looks good overall. Maybe change HelloREEF and the other examples to use it. That way, we set precedent for this new and easier API.

LGTM, within the current protocols. I think a much nicer way would be possible if we were to redefine the underlying evaluator heartbeat protocol. Then, we could define all the special cases of whether or not the exception is present, serializable and if so by which serializer down to the protocol level. But that's the topic of another set of JIRAs :)

+1 on merging.

I've verified normal scenarios (removing evaluator in case of evaluator completion or failure) by running tests with increased logging and looking for relevant log entries. It's a bit tricky to write a good test for this.

+1 for merge.

The tests verify that if `OnNext(ActiveContextManager)` is called, it has correct values, but it doesn't verify that it actually gets called. We can add a global flag which `OnNext` would update when called, and test would check that the flag is set (in `InitializeActiveContextManager`).
